text: Think of it this way: the 4 million who've signed the Cancel Brexit petition shows at least the *potential* pool of voters available to any party that emerges from @TheIndGroup
author: Morkins

text: That's the crack Whipping intelligence that led her to the first and fourth biggest Government defeats ever.
author: Morkins

text: The enormity of the mistake Tory MPs made in having the No Confidence vote in May prematurely is only now becoming fully apparent. She surely would be in serious danger of losing it now.
author: Morkins

text: Yes, the Cancel Brexit petition is getting legitimate scorn from Brexiteers. But, imagine for a sec there was a No Deal Now petition that got over 3 million signatures. They would be going on about it CONSTANTLY.
author: Morkins

text: Which? magazine choosing to focus on the *real* existential crisis facing the country this month.
author: Morkins

text: The Ostrich later buried its head and could be heard to mutter "It's either my deal or no deal or no Brexit".
author: Morkins

text: Ostrich stops traffic in Colchester. There's a Brexit metaphor here somewhere.
author: Morkins

text: I think this petition thing could really take off, but it needs to be regulated. You could have like a single day in which EVERYONE has the opportunity to give their view, privately, in some kind of "booth". They could even "vote" by "post" if they can't get to the "booth".
author: Morkins

text: The UK is NOT a failed state. It just needs a Prime Minister with a Parliamentary majority and a party that is willing to be led by him/her. This is a political crisis caused by political failure.
author: Morkins

text: No Prime Ministerial statement is better than a bad Prime Ministerial statement.
author: Morkins

text: Not getting excited about May statement. Fool me once, shame on you. Fool me thirty-seven times, shame on me.
author: Morkins

text: I can confirm that I walked out of the meeting with Theresa May because the basket of kittens I specified was not provided.
author: Morkins

text: So this means that nearly 60% of people blame the Government either partially or entirely for the Brexit impasse.
author: Morkins
